title: TECH3 Applied statistics
text: This module is about probability, random variables, etc..
crumbs: Module 2: Probability, random variables, probability distributions and simulations.

title: TECH3 Applied statistics
text: In this module, you will learn about summarizing and visualizing data. All (almost) applied statistical analysis starts with some data, and beeing able to summarizing visualize data is an important tool for any user of statistics.

title: TECH3 Applied statistics
text: The following is a redistribution of chapters 3-4 of Statistical Thinking for the 21st Century by Russell A. Poldrack, 2019, under the CC BY-NC 4.0 licence.

title: Exercises
text:
A probability distribution is a function defined on the sample space which is non-negative and such that the sum of all function values is \(1=100\ \%\).


An experiment can have three different outcomes, A, B, or C. The experiment is repeated twice, and the probabilities for the different outcomes are given in the table below.

Why is this a probability distribution?
How large is the probability that we get the outcome A in the first experiment?
How large is the probability that we get A as an outcome of the second experiment?
Does the outcome of the first experiment affect the probabilities of the outcomes of the second experiment?




An experiment can have three different outcomes, A, B, or C. The experiment is repeated twice, and the probabilities for the different outcomes are given in the table below.




AA
AB
AC
BA
BB
BC
CA
CB
CC




Probability (%)
16
12
12
12
9
9
12
9
9




Why is this a probability distribution?
How large is the probability that we get the outcome A in the first experiment?
How large is the probability that we get A as an outcome of the second experiment?
Does the outcome of the first experiment affect the probabilities of the outcomes of the second experiment?




Recall the general addition rule: \[P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B).\]

Assume that \(P(A)=0.2,P(B)=0.3, P(A\cap B)=0.1\). What is \(P(A\cup B)\)?
Assume that \(P(A)=0.3,P(B)=0.4, P(A\cup B)=0.5\). What is \(P(A\cap B)\)?
Assume that \(P(B)=0.4, P(A\cap B)=0.1,P(A\cup B)=0.6\). What is \(P(A)\)?
Assume that \(P(A)=0.5, P(A\cap B)=0.2,P(A\cup B)=0.7\). What is \(P(B)\)?





How do we compute a conditional probability? \[P(A|B)={{P(A\cap B)}\over{P(B)}}\] We must find the probability of the intersection and divide the answer by the probability of the conditioning event.

Assume that \(P(A)=0.5,P(B)=0.3, P(A\cap B)=0.15\). What is \(P(A|B)\)?
Is it always true that \(P(A|B)=P(B|A)\)?
Assume that \(P(B)=0.3,P(A|B)=0.7\). What is \(P(A\cap B)\)?
Assume that \(P(A)=0.3,P(B)=0.6, P(A|B)=0.4\). Find \(P(A\cap B)\) and use the answer to compute \(P(B|A)\).




Bayes law says: \[P(B|A)=P(A|B)\cdot {{P(B)}\over{P(A)}}.\]
Assume that \(P(A)=0.3,P(B)=0.6, P(A|B)=0.4\) (as in 1(d)). Use Bayes’ law to compute \(P(B|A)\).



If we split the sample space into \(n\) non-overlapping parts \(B_1,\dots,B_n\), then \[P(A)=P(A|B_1)\cdot P(B_1)+P(A|B_2)\cdot P(B_2)+\cdots+P(A|B_n)\cdot P(B_n).\] The most common application uses \(n=2\). In that case there are only two terms.

Assume that \(P(B)=0.3, P(A|B)=0.5, P(A|B^c)=0.4\). Find \(P(A)\).
Assume that \(P(A)=0.6, P(B)=0.4,P(A|B^c)=0.5\). Find \(P(A|B)\).




A financial analyst have considered the future development of several differnt stocks. One year later 20% of these stocks did better than the index, 30% performed approximately as the index, while the rest, 50%, performed considerably worse. 60% of the companies that were performing better than the index were rated A by the analyst, 5% of the companies at level with the index had the same rating, while only 3% of the stocks with bad performance were rated A.

How many % of the stocks rated by the analyst, was rated A?
What was that probablity of performing better than the index, given that the stock was rated A by the analyst?




Under a trial concerning alleged women’s discrimination (Berkeley, 1973) the following evidence were presented:

The students had applied for admission to 6 different institutes, and the numbers for the woman applicants were as follows:




Institute
A
B
C
D
E
F


Fraction admitted (%)
82
68
34
35
24
7


Fraction of female applicants (%)
6
1
32
20
22
19



The applicants only applied for admission to one institute. Find the fraction of female applicants that were admitted.

The corresponding results for men were as follows:




Institute
A
B
C
D
E
F


Fraction admitted (%)
62
63
37
33
28
6


Fraction of male applicants (%)
32
22
12
16
7
11



Find the fraction of male applicants that were admitted.

The results from (a) and (b) imply that men had approximately 50% higher chance of being admitted. Was the women discriminated? What is the cause that so few women were admitted?




How do we find the absolute probabilities in a tree with conditional probabilities? We find the unconditional probabilities multiplying along each branch.
The results from a poll is summarized in the tree below.



Probability Tree



How many percent of young men answered no on the question? How many percent of older women answered yes?
Convert the tree to a tree with absolute probabilities.
How many percent answered yes on the question in this poll? How many percent of the women answered yes?

title: Exercises
text:
Recall the general addition rule: \[P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A\cap B).\]

Assume that \(P(A)=0.2,P(B)=0.3, P(A\cap B)=0.1\). What is \(P(A\cup B)\)?
Assume that \(P(A)=0.3,P(B)=0.4, P(A\cup B)=0.5\). What is \(P(A\cap B)\)?
Assume that \(P(B)=0.4, P(A\cap B)=0.1,P(A\cup B)=0.6\). What is \(P(A)\)?
Assume that \(P(A)=0.5, P(A\cap B)=0.2,P(A\cup B)=0.7\). What is \(P(B)\)?

title: Exercises
text:

Assume that \(P(A)=0.5,P(B)=0.3, P(A\cap B)=0.15\). What is \(P(A|B)\)?

title: About
text:
Sondre Hølleland,  Assistant professor





Geir Drage Berentsen,  Associate professor



This course and website has been developed by Sondre Hølleland, assistant professor, and Geir Drage Berentsen, associate professor, both at Norwegian School of Economics, Department of Business and Management Science. More about us will be added.

title: Country data - wrangling
text:
Wrangling of countries data into a single dataset

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



country codes with continent from https://datahub.io/core/country-codes

# north america is coded as NA so need to exclude it from NA list
country_codes <- read_delim('country_codes.csv', na=c('')) %>%
    rename(CountryCode = `ISO3166-1-Alpha-3`, 
           Name = `UNTERM English Formal`) %>%
    select(Continent, CountryCode)

Rows: 250 Columns: 56
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (48): FIFA, Dial, ISO3166-1-Alpha-3, MARC, is_independent, ISO3166-1-num...
dbl  (5): Intermediate Region Code, M49, Sub-region Code, Region Code, Geona...
num  (2): GAUL, ISO4217-currency_minor_unit
lgl  (1): Global Code

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




from google, this contains latitude/longitude

countries <- read_delim('countries/countries.csv') %>%
  rename(CountryName = name)

Rows: 245 Columns: 4
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): country, name
dbl (2): latitude, longitude

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




from worldbank, this contains population over time


years are in columns

population <- read_csv('worldbank/API_SP.POP.TOTL_DS2_en_csv_v2_3469297.csv', show_col_types = FALSE, skip=4) %>% 
  select(-`...66`) %>%
  rename(CountryName = `Country Name`,
         CountryCode = `Country Code`,
         Population2020 = `2020`) %>%
  select(CountryName, CountryCode, Population2020)

New names:
• `` -> `...66`



country_metadata <- read_csv('worldbank/Metadata_Country_API_SP.POP.TOTL_DS2_en_csv_v2_3469297.csv', show_col_types = FALSE) %>% 
  select(-`...6`) %>%
  rename(CountryCode = `Country Code`) %>%
  select(-SpecialNotes, -TableName)

New names:
• `` -> `...6`



popdata <- merge(population, country_metadata, by='CountryCode') %>%
  drop_na(Region)  # remove regional summaries

popdata <- merge(popdata, country_codes, by='CountryCode') %>%
  drop_na(Continent)


popdata_with_geodata <- merge(popdata, countries, by="CountryName")


gdp <- read_csv('worldbank_gdp/API_NY.GDP.MKTP.CD_DS2_en_csv_v2_3469429.csv', show_col_types = FALSE, skip=4) %>% 
  select(-`...66`) %>%
  rename(CountryName = `Country Name`,
         CountryCode = `Country Code`,
         GDP2020 = `2020`)  %>%
  select(CountryCode, GDP2020) %>%
  drop_na(GDP2020)

New names:
• `` -> `...66`

popdata_with_geodata_and_gdp <- merge(popdata_with_geodata, gdp)


write_csv(popdata_with_geodata_and_gdp, 'country_data.csv')

title: Introduction
text:
Welcome to the website for TECH3 Applied Statistics. We will use this website as a supplement to lectures. The website is an ongoing development, so not all subjects will have content yet. Below you will find a detailed (preliminary) lecture plan, link to the textbook and curriculum.






Statistical Thinking in the 21st Century
Python Companion to Statistical Thinking in the 21st Century




All the material on this website, including chapters 1-10, 12-15, and 17 of Statistical Thinking in the 21st Century and Python Companion to Statistical Thinking in the 21st Century.

text:
Statistical Thinking in the 21st Century

title: Python
text:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()







Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
